org.activebpel.rt.bpel.def.visitors
Class AeDefVariableUsageVisitor

java.lang.Object
  org.activebpel.rt.bpel.def.visitors.AeAbstractDefVisitor
      org.activebpel.rt.bpel.def.visitors.AeDefVariableUsageVisitor
All Implemented Interfaces:
IAeDefVisitor
Direct Known Subclasses:
AeWSBPELDefVariableUsageVisitor
public class AeDefVariableUsageVisitor
extends AeAbstractDefVisitor

Visitor that compiles a set of variables used for each activity. This set will be stored on each activity's def object and is used as part of the variable locking process and the implementation of serializable scopes.

traverse

protected void traverse(AeBaseDef aDef)
Called by all of the visit methods in order to traverse the tree. Serves as a good place to record the def if it's an activity because we'll be revisiting all of the def objects to install empty sets if there are no serialized scopes within this process def.

Overrides:
traverse in class AeAbstractDefVisitor

aDef -

parseForVariables

protected void parseForVariables(AeActivityDef aDef,
                                 IAeQueryDef aQueryDef)
Uses the query parser to look for any signs of variable usage within the string passed in. This includes the built in bpel functions getVariableProperty and getVariableData. If these are found then a shared lock is added since we're only reading the variable and not updating it. TODO (EPW) currently this assumes that the query is an XPath query. If we want to support other query languages, his will need to change.

Parameters:
aDef -
aQueryDef -

parseForVariables

protected void parseForVariables(AeActivityDef aDef,
                                 IAeExpressionDef aExpressionDef)
Uses the expression parser to look for any signs of variable usage within the string passed in. This includes the built in bpel functions getVariableProperty and getVariableData. If these are found then a shared lock is added since we're only reading the variable and not updating it.

Parameters:
aDef -
aExpressionDef -

addVariableLock

protected void addVariableLock(AeActivityDef aDef,
                               java.lang.String aVarName,
                               AeDefVariableUsageVisitor.AeLockType aLockType)
We'll record the usage of the variable based on the lock type and whether or not the activity is nested within a serializable scope. In all cases, we record a lock if it's a write lock. This is because the rules for a serializable scope say that a variable should not change once the scope is entered. If an activity outside of the serializable scope wants to write to a variable then it must obtain a write lock and as such, we're recording that requirement here. If we're in a serializable scope however, we acquire a lock irrespective of the lock flag since the serializable scope acquires locks on all of the variables its using to prevent another serializable scope from accessing these same variables until the locks are released. This prevents the issue of dirty reads and non-repeatable reads.

Parameters:
aDef - - the def that uses the variable
aVarName - - the name of the variable
aLockType - - true if we're adding a write lock

getResourcesUsedSet

protected java.util.Set getResourcesUsedSet(AeActivityDef aActivityDef)
Gets or creates the the set that stores the variables used for this def.

Parameters:
aActivityDef -

getPathForVariable

private java.lang.String getPathForVariable(java.lang.String aVarName)
Walks up the stack looking for an AeScopeDef that defines the variable passed in. We should ALWAYS find one or we have a bad bpel file.

Parameters:
aVarName -

getCurrentLocationPath

protected java.lang.String getCurrentLocationPath()
Gets the location path of the item on the stack

isInIsolatedScope

protected boolean isInIsolatedScope(AeActivityDef aDef)
Returns true if we're within a serializable scope. This also takes into consideration the possibility of being within the serializable scope's compensation handler which is technically not part of the serializable requirement.

getTargetForLock

protected AeActivityDef getTargetForLock(AeActivityDef aDef)
The target for the lock is either going to be the def passed in or it'll be the serializable scope if we're within a serializable scope. The latter is because the serializable scope will acquire the locks for all of its nested activities prior to execution. This ensures that we won't have any deadlocks and also frees the individual child activities from having to store any lock information.

Parameters:
aDef -

findParentActivityDef

protected AeActivityDef findParentActivityDef()
Walks the stack from the current position up til it finds an instanceof AeActivityDef to return.

visit

setCompensationHandler

private void setCompensationHandler(AeCompensationHandlerDef aCompensationHandler)
Sets the current compensation handler. As stated in the spec, serializable scopes do not need to acquire locks for activities within their compensation handler. This is because the execution of a compensation handler occurs after the normal execution of the scope and is therefore outside of the bounds of the scope's serializable requirements.

getCompensationHandler

protected AeCompensationHandlerDef getCompensationHandler()
Returns the current compensation handler or null.

visit

public void visit(AeProcessDef aDef)
If there are no serializable scopes within the process def then the visitor will install Collections.EMPTY_SET for each of the activity defs since no variable locking is required.

Specified by:
visit in interface IAeDefVisitor
Overrides:
visit in class AeAbstractDefVisitor
